REPLY TO RESPONSE TO MOTION TO APPOINT GUARDIAN AD LITEM
COMES NOW, Petitioner BRITTANY GILLILAND, by and through the undersigned
counsel of record, Barbara H. Agricola, with the law firm of Agricola Law, LLC, and files this
Reply to Response to Motion to Appoint Guardian Ad Litem. In support thereof, Petitioner states
as follows:
1. Respondent alleges that Petitioner’s Motion to Appoint Guardian Ad Litem is without
merit. However, Respondent has consistently acted in bad faith and continues to
involve Minor Children in this present action;
2. Respondent has revealed details of the present action to Minor Children in order to
further drive a wedge between Petitioner and the Minor Children. This includes
statements that Petitioner is the reason why the Minor Children, particularly A.K., are
required to participate in family dinners and reunification therapy. This has led A.K. to
misunderstand the details surrounding this present action and the Court’s orders that
have been made in A.K.’s best interest;
Brittany Michelle Gilliland v. Christopher Blaine McGregor
Circuit Court of Tallapoosa County, Alabama
Case No.: 70-DR-2023-900051.01
Reply to Response to Motion to Appoint GAL
Page 1 of 3
DOCUMENT 102
3. Respondent has “unclean hands” and therefore should not be exempt from all costs
associated with the appointment of a Guardian Ad Litem, as it is the Respondent’s
actions that have led Petitioner to take this measure;
4. Furthermore, Respondent has recently filed for bankruptcy and is no longer paying
Petitioner the $2,000.00 a month she is owed in equity payments from the Final Divorce
Order. As a result, Petitioner is in a horrible financial position because Respondent
continues to game the system to avoid compliance with the Court’s Final Order of
Divorce.
5. Should a Guardian Ad Litem be appointed, both Parties shall equally split the costs.
WHEREFORE, PREMISES CONSIDERED, the Petitioner respectfully requests that this
Honorable Court GRANT this Motion and appoint a Guardian ad Litem for the Minor Children
with the costs to be split between the Parties.
Respectfully submitted on December 20, 2024.
